citations.citation: Pub. L. 106-224, Title IV, Subtitle C

para.text: REPEAL.—The following provisions of law are repealed:
The Act of August 20, 1912 (commonly known as the "Plant Quarantine Act") (7 U.S.C. 151-164a, 167).
The Federal Plant Pest Act (7 U.S.C. 150aa et seq. and 7 U.S.C. 147a note).
Subsections (a) through (e) of section 102 of the Department of Agriculture Organic Act of 1944 (7 U.S.C. 147a).
The Federal Noxious Weed Act of 1974 (7 U.S.C. 2801 et seq.), except the first section and section 15 of that Act (7 U.S.C. 2801 note and 7 U.S.C. 2814).
The Act of January 31, 1942 (commonly known as the "Mexican Border Act") (7 U.S.C. 149).
The Joint Resolution of April 6, 1937 (commonly known as the "Insect Control Act") (7 U.S.C. 148 et seq.).
The Halogeton Glomeratus Act (7 U.S.C. 1651 et seq.).
The Golden Nematode Act (7 U.S.C. 150 et seq.).
Section 1773 of the Food Security Act of 1985 (Public Law 99-198; 7 U.S.C. 148f).
EMERGENCY TRANSFER AUTHORITY REGARDING PLANT PESTS.—The first section of Public Law 97-46 (7 U.S.C. 147b) is amended—
by striking "section 102 of the Act of September 21, 1944, as amended (7 U.S.C. 147a), and".

EFFECT ON REGULATIONS.—Regulations issued under the authority of a provision of law repealed by subsection (a) shall remain in effect until such time as the Secretary issues a regulation under section 434 that supersedes the earlier regulation.
